title: Use AskUserQuestion in continue command for session selection
description:
When `/dots-swe:continue` is run without a bead ID, it currently just lists the available sessions. 

Enhancement: Use AskUserQuestion to present the list of active beads/worktrees as selectable options instead of just listing them.

This provides a better UX by allowing users to select from available sessions interactively.
close_reason: Implemented interactive session selection using AskUserQuestion. Continue command now presents available sessions as options when no bead ID is provided. Added --format=json flag to continue.sh for programmatic parsing. Version bumped to 1.2.0.

title: Claude calls Skill tool when command already loaded
description:
## Bug

When user invokes a skill directly (e.g., `/dots-swe:status`), the system loads the skill with `<command-message>` and `<command-name>` tags. According to system instructions, Claude should NOT call the Skill tool in this case - the skill is already loaded.

**Current Behavior:**
1. User types `/dots-swe:status`
2. System injects skill content with `<command-name>/dots-swe:status</command-name>`
3. Claude calls the Skill tool anyway
4. Skill tool returns "Launching skill: dots-swe:status" (no output)
5. System re-sends the skill content
6. Claude finally executes the bash command

**Expected Behavior:**
1. User types `/dots-swe:status`
2. System injects skill content with `<command-name>` tag
3. Claude sees the tag and immediately executes the `!bash` command
4. Output is shown to user

**Root Cause:**
Claude system prompt says: "If you see a <command-name> tag in the current conversation turn, the skill has ALREADY been loaded and its instructions follow in the next message. Do NOT call this tool - just follow the skill instructions directly."

Claude is not following this instruction.

**Impact:**
- Extra round trip (wasted context/time)
- No output shown until user interrupts
- Confusing UX

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Update claude-instructions in skill files to clarify when to use Skill tool vs when skill is already loaded
- [ ] Add clear guidance: if `<command-name>` tag present, execute bash directly
- [ ] Test with `/dots-swe:status` to verify immediate output
- [ ] Document the pattern for all skill authors

title: Include bead ID in task completion message
description:
## Enhancement

Update the completion message format to include the bead ID.

**Current:**
"The work completed for this task includes"

**Desired:**
"The work completed for task [BEAD_ID] includes"

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Find where this message is generated (likely in SWE agent or completion workflow)
- [ ] Update message template to include the bead ID variable
- [ ] Verify message shows correctly with actual bead ID

comments.author: Robert (Kenpo) Evans
comments.text: Code complete - quality gates passed, ready for PR and merge

title: [BUG] worktree-create skill loops don't execute - \! prefix only works on single lines
close_reason: Fixed by moving loop logic to library functions in worktree-lib.sh

comments.author: robert
comments.text:
## Problem

The `!for` loop syntax in skill markdown doesn't work as intended. Only lines that directly start with `!` are executed as bash commands. The body of loops is displayed as text but NOT executed.

## Example (worktree-create.md)

```markdown
!for branch in "$@"; do
  BRANCH_NAME="$branch"
  git worktree add -b "$BRANCH_NAME" "$WORKTREE_DIR" "$CURRENT_BRANCH"  # NOT EXECUTED
done
```

The `git worktree add` inside the loop never runs - it's just echoed as text. The skill appears to succeed but no worktree is created.

## Affected Commands

- `/dots-dev:worktree-create`
- `/dots-dev:worktree-delete` 
- Likely others using for loops

## Fix

Refactor skills to use helper functions in `scripts/worktree-lib.sh` instead of inline loops.

title: Fix get_integration_resources undefined in code-integrate.sh
description:
## Bug

The code-integrate.sh script calls `get_integration_resources` at line 240, but this function is not defined in swe-lib.sh.

## Error

```
/Users/robert/.claude/plugins/cache/dots-claude-plugins/dots-swe/2.9.2/scripts/code-integrate.sh: line 240: get_integration_resources: command not found
```

## Impact

Minor - the integration completes successfully, but the error message is confusing.

## Fix

Either:
1. Remove the call to `get_integration_resources` if it's dead code
2. Implement the function in swe-lib.sh if it's needed

## Location

- dots-swe/scripts/code-integrate.sh:240
- dots-swe/scripts/swe-lib.sh (missing function)

title: Tabs are not removed during integration
description:
When running /dots-swe:code-integrate, the Ghostty tabs (zmx sessions) are not being closed/removed after successful integration.

Current behavior:
- code-integrate kills the zmx session
- But the Ghostty tab remains open
- User has to manually close tabs after integration

Expected behavior:
- When code-integrate succeeds, the associated Ghostty tab should close automatically
- This should happen after killing the zmx session

Impact:
- After integrating multiple beads, users are left with many empty/dead tabs
- Manual cleanup is tedious and error-prone
- Reduces the value of automated integration workflow

Files to investigate:
- dots-swe/scripts/code-integrate.sh (cleanup section)
- dots-swe/scripts/swe-lib.sh (zmx session management)

Possible solutions:
1. Use Ghostty-specific commands to close tabs
2. Send exit command to the shell before killing zmx session
3. Use AppleScript to close specific Ghostty tabs by title/identifier

comments.author: Robert (Kenpo) Evans
comments.text:
## Solution Implemented

Added automatic Ghostty tab closing during integration cleanup.

**Implementation:**
1. Created `close_ghostty_tab()` function in swe-lib.sh that uses AppleScript to find and close tabs by session name/title
2. Integrated tab closing into both:
   - `code-integrate.sh`: Closes tabs before killing zmx sessions during integration
   - `delete_worktrees()`: Closes tabs when deleting worktrees via /dots-dev:worktree-delete
3. Updated help text and dry-run messages to reflect new behavior

**Key Features:**
- Uses existing AppleScript permission checking infrastructure
- Fails gracefully if permissions unavailable (doesn't block integration)
- Matches tab title pattern used when creating tabs
- Works for both integration and manual worktree deletion workflows

**Testing Approach:**
To test manually:
1. Create a worktree with /dots-swe:dispatch or /dots-dev:worktree-from-bead
2. Complete work and run /dots-swe:code-complete
3. Run /dots-swe:code-integrate --local <bead-id>
4. Verify that the Ghostty tab closes automatically

**Files Modified:**
- dots-swe/scripts/swe-lib.sh: Added close_ghostty_tab() function, updated delete_worktrees()
- dots-swe/scripts/code-integrate.sh: Integrated tab closing, updated help text

title: Add dependency visualization for beads
description:
## Feature

Create a visual representation of bead dependencies to help understand project structure and identify blockers.

**Goal:**
Make it easy to see dependency chains, identify blocking relationships, and understand epic hierarchies at a glance.

**Proposed Implementation:**

**Option A: New Command** (`/dots-swe:deps`)
- ASCII tree view showing dependency graph
- Highlight ready vs blocked beads
- Show epic relationships

**Option B: Enhance Existing Commands**
- Add `--deps` flag to `bd show`
- Add dependency graph section to `/dots-swe:status`
- Integrate into `bd ready` output

**Visualization Format:**
- ASCII art tree (works in terminal)
- Optional: generate Mermaid/Graphviz for rich docs
- Color coding for status (ready/blocked/in_progress)

**Features:**
1. Show transitive dependencies (A blocks B blocks C)
2. Identify critical path (longest dependency chain)
3. Highlight circular dependencies (if any)
4. Filter by epic, status, priority
5. Show reverse dependencies (what depends on this)

**Example Output:**
```
dots-claude-plugins-epic-1
├─ dots-claude-plugins-abc [ready] ✓
│  └─ dots-claude-plugins-def [blocked] ⏸
│     └─ dots-claude-plugins-ghi [blocked] ⏸
└─ dots-claude-plugins-xyz [in_progress] ◐
```

**Technical Approach:**
1. Query beads database for dependency edges
2. Build directed acyclic graph (DAG)
3. Use tree traversal for ASCII rendering
4. Add to swe-lib.sh as reusable function

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- [ ] Can visualize dependencies for a single bead
- [ ] Can show full project dependency graph
- [ ] Clearly indicates blocked vs ready beads
- [ ] Works with epic hierarchies
- [ ] Performance is acceptable for 100+ beads
- [ ] Integrates cleanly with existing commands

comments.author: Robert (Kenpo) Evans
comments.text:
Implementation complete. Created /dots-swe:deps command with:
- Project overview mode showing epics, blocked issues, and ready work
- Single bead mode with full dependency tree and status indicators
- Mermaid diagram export for documentation
- Enhanced /dots-swe:status with dependency summary
- Updated help and beads documentation
- Version bumped to 2.13.0

All acceptance criteria met.

comments.author: Robert (Kenpo) Evans
comments.text: Code complete - quality gates passed, ready for PR and merge

title: code-complete should rebase onto main before marking complete
description:
## Problem

When running `/dots-swe:code-complete`, branches are marked complete without rebasing onto current main. This causes merge conflicts during integration if main has advanced.

**Example:**
- Branch created from main at commit A
- Work completed on branch
- Main advances to commit D (other work integrated)
- `/dots-swe:code-complete` runs - pushes branch, adds label
- `/dots-swe:code-integrate --local` fails due to conflicts
- Manual rebase required before integration succeeds

## Solution

Update `/dots-swe:code-complete` to:
1. Fetch latest from origin
2. Rebase current branch onto origin/main
3. Run quality gates (test/lint/build)
4. Push to remote
5. Add swe:code-complete label

This ensures branches are always ready to integrate cleanly.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] code-complete.sh fetches origin before running checks
- [ ] Rebases onto origin/main (with --force-with-lease push if needed)
- [ ] Aborts if rebase has conflicts, instructs user to resolve
- [ ] Quality gates run on rebased code
- [ ] Integration succeeds without manual rebase
- [ ] Test with divergent branch scenario

comments.author: Robert (Kenpo) Evans
comments.text: Implementation complete: code-complete now fetches and rebases onto origin/main before running quality gates

title: SWE agents skip quality gates before committing
description:
## Problem

SWE agents (including Claude) consistently skip quality gates (process-check/code-complete) before committing code, despite having guidance to run them. This defeats the purpose of having automated quality checks.

**Recent Example:**
- dots-claude-plugins-ztt: Fixed Skill tool hanging bug
- Changes: Modified 11 command files + created documentation
- Committed and closed bead WITHOUT running quality gates
- No tests, no lint, no verification the fix actually works

## Root Cause Analysis

### 1. bd prime's SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL is Incomplete

The `bd prime` command (from beads-marketplace) outputs a SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL that does NOT include quality gates:

**Current output (ephemeral branch mode):**
```
[ ] 1. git status              (check what changed)
[ ] 2. git add <files>         (stage code changes)
[ ] 3. bd sync --from-main     (pull beads updates from main)
[ ] 4. git commit -m "..."     (commit code changes)
```

**What's missing:** Step 0 should be "Run quality gates"

### 2. Competing/Conflicting Guidance

Multiple sources provide guidance, creating confusion:

- **bd prime SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL**: No quality gates mentioned
- **.swe-context Quick Reference**: Says "Run /dots-swe:process-check before committing"
- **.swe-context Quality Checklist**: Has checkboxes but no enforcement
- **CLAUDE.md Session Completion Protocol**: Mentions quality gates but less prominent

Agents follow the most prominent/structured checklist (SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL) which is incomplete.

### 3. No Enforcement Mechanism

Nothing prevents commits without quality gates:
- No pre-commit hooks to verify
- No TodoWrite template that includes quality gates step
- Acceptance criteria in beads don't include "run quality gates" by default
- Agents create implementation todos but don't add "verify with tests" as final step

### 4. bd prime is Not Our Code

The `bd prime` command lives in `beads-marketplace` (Steve Yegge's repo), not `dots-claude-plugins`. We cannot modify it directly.

**Source:** `/Users/robert/.claude/plugins/marketplaces/beads-marketplace/cmd/bd/prime.go`

## Impact

- **Quality Issues**: Code committed without verification
- **Broken Fixes**: Changes that might not actually work
- **Protocol Violation**: Defeats purpose of having /dots-swe:process-check and /dots-swe:code-complete
- **Normalization**: If agents skip it once, they'll keep skipping it
- **Wasted Effort**: Bugs that should be caught in development slip through

## Why This Happened on dots-claude-plugins-ztt

1. Agent created todo list: "Fix files", "Document pattern", "Commit changes"
2. No todo added for "Run quality gates"
3. Followed bd prime's SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL checklist (no quality gates)
4. Ignored .swe-context guidance (less structured, buried in middle of file)
5. No enforcement stopped the commit
6. Result: Committed untested changes, closed bead

## Proposed Solution

**Create our own prime command in dots-swe that replaces bd prime's output**

```
dots-swe/commands/prime.md
```

This command would:
1. Call bd prime to get base context
2. Override/inject the SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL with our enhanced version
3. Include quality gates as Step 0 (mandatory)
4. Adapt based on project type (skip if no tests/lint detected)

**Enhanced SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL (ephemeral branch):**
```
[ ] 0. Run quality gates        (/dots-swe:process-check OR /dots-swe:code-complete)
[ ] 1. git status              (check what changed)
[ ] 2. git add <files>         (stage code changes)
[ ] 3. bd sync --from-main     (pull beads updates from main)
[ ] 4. git commit -m "..."     (commit code changes)
```

**Implementation Strategy:**
- Make it a SessionStart hook in dots-swe (runs instead of bd prime)
- Detect if project has tests/lint (Makefile, package.json, etc.)
- Output appropriate protocol based on context
- Keep compatibility with bd prime's modes (MCP, stealth, ephemeral)

## Alternative Solutions Considered

1. **Pre-commit git hook**: Too restrictive, blocks agent autonomy
2. **TodoWrite template**: Agents don't always use TodoWrite for all tasks
3. **Update .swe-context**: Already has guidance, agents ignore it
4. **Update CLAUDE.md**: Less effective than prominent checklist
5. **Modify bd prime**: Not our code, can't change it

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Create /dots-swe:prime command that enhances bd prime output
- [ ] Add quality gates as Step 0 in SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL
- [ ] Make it project-aware (detect test/lint/build tools)
- [ ] Set up as SessionStart hook to replace bd prime
- [ ] Test with ephemeral branch workflow
- [ ] Test with MCP mode
- [ ] Document the override mechanism
- [ ] Verify agents actually run quality gates before committing

## Files to Create/Modify

- `dots-swe/commands/prime.md` - New command
- `dots-swe/scripts/prime.sh` - Implementation script
- `dots-swe/hooks/hooks.json` - Update SessionStart hook
- `docs/quality-gates-enforcement.md` - Documentation

## Testing Strategy

1. Create test bead with code changes
2. Agent works on it in worktree with dots-swe:prime
3. Verify agent sees enhanced SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL
4. Confirm agent runs quality gates before committing
5. Test with project that has no tests (should skip gracefully)

comments.author: Robert (Kenpo) Evans
comments.text: Implementation complete. Created dots-swe:prime command that enhances session context with quality gates enforcement. The enhanced SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL now includes Step 0 for running quality gates when tests/lint/build are detected. Automatically runs on SessionStart via hooks.

comments.author: Robert (Kenpo) Evans
comments.text: Code complete - quality gates passed, ready for PR and merge

title: [feature] Auto-detect Xcode projects and use sibling worktrees
description: Worktree creation should auto-detect Xcode projects (*.xcodeproj) and create worktrees as siblings instead of nested in .worktrees/ to avoid Swift Package Manager local dependency path resolution issues. Detection: check for *.xcodeproj in repo root. If found, use ../$(basename $repo)-wt-$name pattern instead of .worktrees/$name pattern.
design: Detection: Look for *.xcodeproj files in the root of the git repo (e.g., ls *.xcodeproj 2>/dev/null). If found, create worktree as sibling using pattern: ../$(basename $PWD)-wt-$name. Otherwise, use existing nested pattern: .worktrees/$name. Modify the worktree-create skill to add this detection logic before the git worktree add command.
acceptance_criteria: 1. Xcode project (has *.xcodeproj): Creates worktree as sibling (../<repo>-wt-<name>), can build in Xcode without SPM path errors. 2. Non-Xcode project: Creates worktree in .worktrees/<name> as before. 3. Verify with real repos: test with Yap (Xcode) and another non-Xcode repo. 4. Git worktree list shows correct paths for both cases.

title: Move 'Ready to Integrate' to top of status report with copy-paste command
description:
Improve the status command UX by making integration opportunities more visible and actionable.

Requirements:
1. Move 'Ready to Integrate' section to be the FIRST section in the status report (before Active Epic)
2. Add a one-liner command that users can copy/paste to integrate all ready beads
   - Format: /dots-swe:code-integrate --local bead1 bead2 bead3
   - Should list all beads with swe:code-complete label
   - Only show if there are beads ready to integrate
3. Keep the existing integration section content (worktrees needing finishing, etc.)

Files to modify:
- dots-swe/scripts/status.sh

Rationale: Integration is the most actionable item and should be surfaced first. Adding a copy-paste command reduces friction for users to complete work.

title: Beads sync.branch configuration error
description:
Beads sync fails with configuration error:

```
Error: sync.branch not configured (run 'bd config set sync.branch <branch-name>')
```

This appears when running doctor or other commands that check sync status. Need to investigate why sync.branch is not properly configured.
close_reason: Fixed both issues. Added doctor.sh script that was missing from plugin installation. Updated beads sync check to treat missing sync.branch configuration as informational rather than an error. Version bumped to 1.1.3.

title: Fix dots plugin manifest command paths
description: The dots plugin manifest has invalid command paths. Commands must start with './' and end with '.md' according to the plugin validation schema. Need to update the commands array to use proper file paths like './commands/vibe-spawn.md' instead of plain strings like 'vibe-spawn'.
close_reason: Fixed plugin manifest command paths to use proper file path format

title: Continue command doesn't properly detect worktrees
description:
The `/dots-swe:continue` command shows sessions as '(no worktree)' even when git worktrees exist.

Example:
```
You have two available sessions you can continue with:
  1. dots-claude-plugins-7vd (no worktree)
  2. test (no worktree)
```

But `git worktree list` shows:
```
/Users/robert/repos/objectiveous/GammaKit/.worktrees/gk-6xv.3  c188130 [gk-6xv.3]
```

The continue script isn't properly detecting or associating worktrees with sessions.
close_reason: Fixed worktree detection. Continue command now uses lsof to get actual working directory from session PID, allowing it to detect worktrees across all repositories. Version bumped to 1.1.2.

title: code-complete should display bead metadata summary at end
description:
## Enhancement

The `/dots-swe:code-complete` command should always display a summary of the bead's metadata at the very end of all output messages.

**Current Behavior:**
Command completes but doesn't show clear summary of what bead was marked complete.

**Desired Behavior:**
At the end of all output, display:
```
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Bead Summary
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

ID:     dots-abc-123
Title:  Fix authentication bug in login flow
Type:   bug
Status: in_progress (marked swe:code-complete)
Parent: dots-abc-100 - User authentication epic
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] code-complete.sh reads .swe-bead to get bead ID
- [ ] Fetches bead metadata using `bd show <id>`
- [ ] Displays formatted summary at end of output
- [ ] Summary includes: ID, Title, Type, Status, Parent (if exists)
- [ ] Parent shows as "None" or omitted if no parent epic
- [ ] Summary appears after quality gates and push operations
- [ ] Test with bead that has parent epic
- [ ] Test with bead that has no parent

## Implementation Notes

Can use `bd show <id>` and parse output, or use `bd show <id> --json` if available.

comments.author: Robert (Kenpo) Evans
comments.text: Code complete - quality gates passed, ready for PR and merge

title: Update SWE agent instructions to mandate code-complete before closing beads
description:
## Problem

The SWE agent instructions (dots-swe/agents/swe.md) do not explicitly mandate running /dots-swe:code-complete before closing beads, leading agents to skip this critical step.

Recent violations:
- dots-claude-plugins-5va: Closed bead without code-complete
- dots-claude-plugins-ztt: Closed bead without quality gates
- Multiple historical instances documented in dots-claude-plugins-65l

## Root Cause Analysis

### Current SWE Agent Guidance Gaps

1. **No explicit code-complete requirement**: swe.md mentions quality gates in abstract terms but doesn't mandate /dots-swe:code-complete as a pre-closing step

2. **Workflow section incomplete**: The workflow example shows:
   - Load context
   - Implement changes
   - Commit with Conventional Commits format
   - ❌ **MISSING**: Run code-complete before closing

3. **Bead closing guidance absent**: No section on "How to properly close a bead" or "Final steps before completion"

4. **Quality gates mentioned but not enforced**:
   - Quality Bar section exists (line ~150)
   - Mentions test/lint/build
   - But doesn't tie it to code-complete command
   - Doesn't say "run this before closing"

5. **Command reference scattered**:
   - /dots-swe:process-check mentioned for interim checks
   - /dots-swe:code-complete not prominently featured
   - Distinction between them unclear

6. **Agent behavior pattern**:
   - Agents implement features correctly
   - Run tests during development (if prompted)
   - But skip final verification before saying "done"
   - Jump straight to: commit → close bead → "complete"

### Why Agents Skip This Step

**Cognitive pattern**:
1. Agent completes implementation
2. Code looks correct
3. Agent commits changes
4. Agent marks bead closed
5. Agent says "implementation complete"

**Missing trigger**: Nothing in instructions says "STOP - run code-complete first"

**False completion signal**: Committing code feels like "done" to the agent

## Solution: Mandatory Code-Complete Section

Add explicit, impossible-to-miss guidance in swe.md that mandates code-complete before closing beads.

### New Section: "CRITICAL: Before Closing Any Bead"

Insert prominently after Quality Bar section (around line ~180):

```markdown
## CRITICAL: Before Closing Any Bead

You MUST run `/dots-swe:code-complete` before closing a bead or saying you're "done". This is NON-NEGOTIABLE.

### What Code-Complete Does

The `/dots-swe:code-complete` command is your final quality gate. It:

1. **Runs all quality gates** (if detected):
   - Tests: Ensures your changes don't break existing functionality
   - Lint: Verifies code style and catches common errors
   - Build: Confirms the project builds successfully

2. **Pushes to remote**: Ensures your code is backed up and visible to CI

3. **Labels the bead**: Adds `swe:code-complete` label indicating work is ready for integration

4. **Displays summary**: Shows what was completed for verification

### When to Run Code-Complete

Run `/dots-swe:code-complete` when:
- ✅ All acceptance criteria are met
- ✅ All code changes are committed locally
- ✅ You're about to close the bead
- ✅ You're about to say "done" or "complete"

**Before running**:
1. Squash commits if needed: `/dots-swe:squash`
2. Ensure all changes committed: `git status` should be clean
3. Review your changes one final time

**After running**:
- If it succeeds: Proceed to close bead and integration
- If it fails: Fix the issue, commit, run code-complete again

### NEVER Do This

❌ **WRONG: Close bead without code-complete**
```bash
git commit -m "feat: add feature"
bd close dots-abc-123
# Agent: "Implementation complete!"
```

✅ **CORRECT: Code-complete, verify, then close**
```bash
git commit -m "feat: add feature"
/dots-swe:code-complete           # ← REQUIRED STEP
# ... code-complete runs quality gates, pushes, labels ...
bd close dots-abc-123              # Only after code-complete succeeds
```

### Why This Matters

Skipping code-complete means:
- ❌ Untested code gets merged
- ❌ Build failures discovered during integration (too late)
- ❌ Wasted time fixing issues that should have been caught earlier
- ❌ Integration delays for other work
- ❌ Loss of confidence in quality process

### Quality Gates Failures

If `/dots-swe:code-complete` fails:

1. **Read the error output carefully**
2. **Identify which gate failed** (test/lint/build)
3. **Fix the issue**:
   - Tests failing: Fix the test or the code
   - Lint failing: Run linter locally and fix issues
   - Build failing: Check build errors and resolve
4. **Commit the fix**
5. **Run code-complete again**
6. **Repeat until it passes**

**DO NOT**:
- ❌ Skip code-complete because "it's probably fine"
- ❌ Close the bead with failing quality gates
- ❌ Commit code that doesn't pass quality gates
- ❌ Ask user to "fix it later"

### Interim vs Final Checks

**During development**: Use `/dots-swe:process-check`
- Runs quality gates only
- No push, no labeling
- Quick feedback loop
- Run as often as needed

**Before closing**: Use `/dots-swe:code-complete`
- Runs quality gates
- Pushes to remote
- Labels bead as complete
- Final verification step
- Run once when done

### Enforcement

The workflow has enforcement mechanisms:
1. **Pre-commit hook**: May prompt if code-complete not run
2. **Doctor command**: Checks for code-complete label
3. **Integration command**: Expects code-complete label

These are safety nets. Don't rely on them. Run code-complete proactively.

### Example: Complete Workflow

```bash
# 1. Squash commits into logical units
/dots-swe:squash

# 2. Verify everything committed
git status  # Should show clean

# 3. Run code-complete (REQUIRED)
/dots-swe:code-complete

# Output:
# ✅ Tests passed (23 tests)
# ✅ Lint passed
# ✅ Build passed
# ✅ Pushed to origin/dots-abc-123
# ✅ Added swe:code-complete label
# 
# Bead Summary:
# ID:     dots-abc-123
# Title:  Add user authentication
# Status: ready for integration

# 4. Only now: close the bead
bd close dots-abc-123

# 5. Integration (usually separate session/later)
/dots-swe:code-integrate dots-abc-123
```
```

### Update Existing Sections

**Workflow section** (around line 42):
Add between "Commit changes" and "After completing work":

```markdown
### 5. Final Verification

Before closing the bead, run final quality gates:

\`\`\`bash
/dots-swe:code-complete
\`\`\`

This ensures your work is tested, linted, built, and ready for integration.
```

**After Completing Work section** (around line 240):
Change from:
```markdown
Next steps:
- Close the bead: `bd close <bead-id>`
- Move on to next bead
```

To:
```markdown
Next steps:
1. Run final quality gates: `/dots-swe:code-complete`
2. If code-complete succeeds:
   - Close the bead: `bd close <bead-id>`
   - Move on to next bead
3. If code-complete fails:
   - Fix the issue
   - Commit the fix
   - Run code-complete again
```

## Why This Works

1. **Impossible to miss**: "CRITICAL" header with explicit mandate
2. **Clear reasoning**: Explains why it matters
3. **Behavioral guidance**: Shows correct vs incorrect patterns
4. **Failure handling**: Tells agent what to do when it fails
5. **Enforcement awareness**: Mentions hooks and checks
6. **Example workflow**: Shows complete end-to-end pattern
7. **Repetition**: Mentioned in multiple sections
8. **Visual emphasis**: ❌ and ✅ symbols, code examples

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Add "CRITICAL: Before Closing Any Bead" section after Quality Bar
- [ ] Section explains what code-complete does (numbered list)
- [ ] Section shows when to run code-complete (✅ checklist)
- [ ] Section shows WRONG vs CORRECT patterns (❌/✅ examples)
- [ ] Section explains why it matters (consequences)
- [ ] Section covers failure handling (step-by-step)
- [ ] Section distinguishes process-check vs code-complete
- [ ] Section shows complete example workflow
- [ ] Update Workflow section to include code-complete step
- [ ] Update "After Completing Work" section with code-complete requirement
- [ ] Add enforcement mechanism mentions
- [ ] Use visual emphasis (❌/✅, CRITICAL, NEVER, MUST)
- [ ] Test: Agent reads updated swe.md and runs code-complete
- [ ] Verify section is prominent and impossible to skip
- [ ] Update version to 2.14.0 (matches protocol change)

## Files to Modify

- `dots-swe/agents/swe.md` - Add CRITICAL section, update workflow
- `dots-swe/commands/help.md` - Update agent description
- `dots-swe/.claude-plugin/plugin.json` - Bump version to 2.14.0

## Integration with Other Solutions

This bead works in conjunction with:
- **dots-claude-plugins-oz4**: Pre-commit hook (enforcement)
- **dots-claude-plugins-rkz**: SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL (checklist)

Together they create defense in depth:
1. **Instructions** (this bead): Education and behavioral guidance
2. **Protocol** (rkz): Visual checklist reminder
3. **Hook** (oz4): Hard enforcement

## Testing Strategy

1. Update swe.md with new section
2. Load swe agent in test session
3. Verify agent sees CRITICAL section
4. Complete test task
5. Observe if agent runs code-complete before closing
6. Test failure scenario (make tests fail)
7. Verify agent handles failure correctly
8. Test with agent that hasn't seen new instructions
9. Compare behavior before/after update

## Success Metrics

Before change:
- Agents skip code-complete ~80% of time

Target after change:
- Agents skip code-complete <10% of time
- When skipped, agent catches it before closing bead
- Failure handling done correctly (fix, commit, retry)

## Rollout Plan

1. Implement changes to swe.md
2. Bump version to 2.14.0
3. Test with new sessions
4. Monitor agent behavior
5. Iterate on wording if agents still skip
6. Document in changelog

## Edge Cases

**No quality gates detected**: Code-complete still runs (pushes, labels)
**Quality gates fail**: Agent should fix and retry, not skip
**Pre-commit hook not installed**: Agent should still run code-complete
**GitHub PR workflow**: Slightly different (creates PR instead of local merge)

title: [TASK] Create dots-claude-plugins marketplace

title: Fix commit and merge hygiene to follow Conventional Commits
design:
## Problem
Current commit/merge practices violate Conventional Commits and will cause problems at scale:
1. Merge commits use generic messages like 'Merge branch X' instead of summarizing work
2. No squashing strategy - feature branches dump many micro-commits to main
3. Commit hook doesn't handle merge commits properly
4. bd sync commits bypass conventions (LOW PRIORITY)

## Expert Best Practices (2026)
- Main branch should contain one commit per feature/fix
- Feature branches can have many commits, but squash before merge
- Merge commits should follow Conventional Commits format and summarize work
- Commit hooks should allow/validate merge commits differently

## Design Approach

### 1. Local Merge Workflow (Primary)
Since only one developer and local CI/CD:
- Update merge commands to prompt for Conventional Commit message
- Include summary of branch changes in merge commit body
- Use --no-ff to preserve branch topology

### 2. Squashing Strategy
- Add pre-merge squash step to workflow
- Guide users through interactive rebase
- Keep main branch clean with logical commits

### 3. Commit Hook Enhancement
- Detect merge commits (start with 'Merge')
- Allow merge commits to pass (different validation)
- Continue validating regular commits

### 4. Documentation Updates
- Update SWE agent with squash workflow
- Update all commands to reference squashing
- Add examples of good merge messages

## Out of Scope
- GitHub PR title validation (no GitHub CI/CD)
- GitHub Actions (using local CI/CD)
- Multi-developer coordination (single dev currently)
- bd sync commit format (LOW PRIORITY - defer to later)
acceptance_criteria:
## Exit Criteria

### Merge Commits Follow Convention
- Merge commands generate Conventional Commit messages
- Merge messages include type(scope): description format
- Merge commit body summarizes changes from branch
- Example: 'feat(auth): add OAuth integration' not 'Merge branch oauth'

### Squashing Workflow Implemented
- Documentation explains when/how to squash commits
- SWE agent includes squashing in workflow
- Helper command exists for interactive rebasing
- Main branch shows clean, logical commit history

### Commit Hook Handles Merges
- Hook allows merge commits to pass
- Hook still validates regular commits
- No false rejections of valid merge commits
- Can complete a merge without hook errors

### Documentation Updated
- SWE agent includes squash workflow
- Merge commands reference Conventional Commits format
- Examples show good vs bad commit messages
- Quick reference cards updated

### Manual Testing
Test 1: Merge with conventional commit message works
Test 2: Squashing workflow guides through rebase
Test 3: Hook validation still works for bad messages
Test 4: Regular conventional commits pass

## Success Metrics
- Zero non-conventional commits in main branch (except historical)
- Average 1-3 commits per feature (not 10-20 micro-commits)
- All merge commits follow type(scope): format
- Commit hook has 0% false positive rate

title: Update merge commands to use Conventional Commit format

Target: Prompt for conventional message and include change summary
design:
## Current Implementation
dots-dev/commands/worktree-merge.md:39 uses generic merge message

## New Implementation
1. Before merge, show git log main..branch --oneline
2. Prompt user for Conventional Commit message:
   - Type (feat/fix/chore/refactor/etc)
   - Scope (optional)
   - Description
3. Generate merge commit with:
   - Subject: type(scope): description
   - Body: summary of commits being merged
   - Footer: 'Merged branch: <branch-name>'

## Example
Subject: feat(auth): add OAuth integration
Body:
- Add OAuth 2.0 provider configuration
- Implement token refresh logic
- Add session management

Merged branch: feature/oauth

## Command: /dots-swe:squash

New file: dots-swe/commands/squash.md

1. Check if on feature branch (not main)
2. Check if branch has commits ahead of main
3. Show commit count and list
4. Offer to start interactive rebase
5. Provide guidance during rebase

Commits to squash: 3
dfc930a wip: c
c900242 wip: b
59532f2 wip: a

Starting interactive rebase...
In the editor:
  - Keep first commit as 'pick'
  - Change others to 'squash' (keep message) or 'fixup' (discard message)
  - Save and close
  - Write final Conventional Commit message

bd sync auto-generates commits like:

→ No upstream configured, using --from-main mode

- Only affects sync commits, not code commits
- Single developer workflow
- Can be done last after other hygiene improvements

title: Add pre-commit hook to enforce code-complete workflow
description:
## Problem

SWE agents consistently skip /dots-swe:code-complete before committing code, despite documentation and guidance. Recent examples:
- dots-claude-plugins-5va: Committed without running code-complete
- dots-claude-plugins-ztt: Committed without quality gates
- dots-claude-plugins-65l: Root cause analysis of this pattern

This violates the quality gates protocol and defeats the purpose of having automated quality checks.

## Root Cause Analysis

### Why Agents Skip Code-Complete

1. **No enforcement mechanism**: Nothing blocks commits without code-complete
2. **Guidance is passive**: SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL shows checklist but doesn't enforce it
3. **Multiple competing patterns**: 
   - SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL says "Run quality gates" (ambiguous)
   - Git workflow is familiar (git add → git commit)
   - Agents default to standard git workflow when unsure
4. **Cognitive load**: By the time work is done, agents focus on "commit and close" rather than "verify quality first"
5. **False confidence**: When implementation looks correct, agents assume quality is fine
6. **No immediate feedback**: Skipping code-complete has no immediate negative consequence

### Why This Is Critical

- **Quality regression**: Code committed without tests/lint/build verification
- **Protocol erosion**: If skipped once, becomes normalized behavior
- **Integration failures**: Code that breaks during /dots-swe:code-integrate
- **Wasted effort**: Having to fix issues that should have been caught earlier
- **Lost benefits**: Defeats entire purpose of quality gates infrastructure

## Solution: Pre-commit Git Hook

Create interactive pre-commit hook that checks if bead has swe:code-complete label before allowing commit.

### Implementation

**New command**: `/dots-swe:install-quality-hook`

Creates `.git/hooks/pre-commit`:

```bash
#!/bin/bash
# Pre-commit hook: Enforce code-complete workflow for SWE beads

# Check if we're in a worktree with a bead
BEAD_ID=$(cat .swe-bead 2>/dev/null)

if [ -z "$BEAD_ID" ]; then
  # Not a bead worktree, allow commit
  exit 0
fi

# Check if bead has swe:code-complete label
if bd show "$BEAD_ID" 2>/dev/null | grep -q "swe:code-complete"; then
  # Has label, all good
  exit 0
fi

# Missing swe:code-complete label - prompt user
echo ""
echo "━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━"
echo "⚠️  Quality Gates Check"
echo "━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━"
echo ""
echo "Bead: $BEAD_ID"
echo "Status: Missing swe:code-complete label"
echo ""
echo "Before committing completed work, you should run:"
echo "  /dots-swe:code-complete"
echo ""
echo "This will:"
echo "  • Run quality gates (test/lint/build)"
echo "  • Push to remote"
echo "  • Add swe:code-complete label"
echo "  • Verify work is ready for integration"
echo ""
echo "Options:"
echo "  [y] Yes, I ran code-complete (proceed with commit)"
echo "  [n] No, let me run it now (abort commit)"
echo "  [w] This is WIP, skip for now (proceed with commit)"
echo ""
read -p "Continue with commit? [y/n/w]: " -n 1 -r
echo ""

case "$REPLY" in
  y|Y)
    echo "✓ Proceeding with commit"
    exit 0
    ;;
  w|W)
    echo "⚠️  Proceeding with WIP commit (code-complete skipped)"
    exit 0
    ;;
  *)
    echo "❌ Commit aborted"
    echo ""
    echo "Next steps:"
    echo "  1. Run: /dots-swe:code-complete"
    echo "  2. If quality gates pass, commit again"
    echo ""
    exit 1
    ;;
esac
```

### Hook Management

**Install**: `/dots-swe:install-quality-hook`
- Creates/updates pre-commit hook
- Makes it executable
- Confirms installation

**Uninstall**: `/dots-swe:uninstall-quality-hook`
- Removes pre-commit hook
- Confirms removal

**Check**: Part of `/dots-swe:doctor`
- Verifies hook is installed
- Warns if missing

### User Experience

**Scenario 1: Agent tries to commit without code-complete**
```bash
$ git commit -m "feat: add new feature"

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
⚠️  Quality Gates Check
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Bead: dots-abc-123
Status: Missing swe:code-complete label

Before committing completed work, you should run:
  /dots-swe:code-complete

Continue with commit? [y/n/w]: n

❌ Commit aborted
Run: /dots-swe:code-complete
```

**Scenario 2: Agent ran code-complete (label exists)**
```bash
$ git commit -m "feat: add new feature"
[branch abc123] feat: add new feature
```
(Hook passes silently)

**Scenario 3: WIP commit**
```bash
Continue with commit? [y/n/w]: w
⚠️  Proceeding with WIP commit (code-complete skipped)
[branch abc123] wip: partial implementation
```

### Why This Works

1. **Active enforcement**: Blocks commit until acknowledged
2. **Educational**: Explains why and what to do
3. **Flexible**: Allows WIP commits when needed
4. **Non-invasive**: Silent when label exists
5. **Clear feedback**: Agent knows immediately if they skipped step
6. **Behavioral training**: Repeated exposure builds habit

### Integration Points

**Dispatch workflow**:
- Hook automatically installed when creating worktree
- Part of workspace setup

**Doctor command**:
- Checks if hook installed
- Offers to install if missing

**Documentation**:
- Update workflow docs to mention hook
- Add troubleshooting section

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Create /dots-swe:install-quality-hook command
- [ ] Create /dots-swe:uninstall-quality-hook command
- [ ] Pre-commit hook checks for .swe-bead file
- [ ] Hook checks for swe:code-complete label via bd show
- [ ] Interactive prompt with clear options (y/n/w)
- [ ] Abort commit if user selects 'n'
- [ ] Allow commit if user selects 'y' or 'w'
- [ ] Silent pass-through when label exists
- [ ] Hook is executable (chmod +x)
- [ ] Update /dots-swe:doctor to check hook status
- [ ] Update /dots-swe:dispatch to install hook in new worktrees
- [ ] Test: Commit without label shows prompt
- [ ] Test: Commit with label passes silently
- [ ] Test: Selecting 'n' aborts commit
- [ ] Test: Selecting 'w' allows commit
- [ ] Document in help.md

## Files to Create/Modify

- `dots-swe/commands/install-quality-hook.md` (new)
- `dots-swe/commands/uninstall-quality-hook.md` (new)
- `dots-swe/scripts/install-quality-hook.sh` (new)
- `dots-swe/scripts/uninstall-quality-hook.sh` (new)
- `dots-swe/scripts/doctor.sh` (modify - add hook check)
- `dots-swe/scripts/dispatch.sh` (modify - auto-install hook)
- `dots-swe/commands/help.md` (modify - document new commands)

## Testing Strategy

1. Create test bead without label
2. Try to commit - should prompt
3. Select 'n' - should abort
4. Run code-complete
5. Commit again - should pass silently
6. Test WIP flow with 'w' option
7. Test hook bypass with --no-verify
8. Test doctor detection

comments.author: Robert (Kenpo) Evans

title: Tabs should have titles set to bead ID

When dispatching beads and opening new Ghostty tabs, the tab title should be set to the bead ID for easy identification.

Currently, tabs opened via /dots-swe:dispatch don't have meaningful titles, making it hard to identify which tab corresponds to which bead when multiple tabs are open.

Requirements:
1. Set tab title to bead ID when opening new Ghostty tabs
2. Update open_ghostty_zmx_tab function in swe-lib.sh
3. Title should persist throughout the session
4. Use terminal escape sequences or Ghostty-specific commands to set title

Files to modify:
- dots-swe/scripts/swe-lib.sh (open_ghostty_zmx_tab function)

Example:
- Tab for bead 'dots-claude-plugins-abc' should show 'dots-claude-plugins-abc' as the tab title

This improves UX when working with multiple beads simultaneously.

title: Enhance SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL to explicitly require code-complete
description:
## Problem

The SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL displayed by dots-swe:prime is ambiguous about quality gates, leading agents to skip /dots-swe:code-complete before committing.

**Current protocol:**
```
[ ] 1. git status              (check what changed)
[ ] 2. git add <files>         (stage code changes)
[ ] 3. bd sync --from-main     (pull beads updates from main)
[ ] 4. git commit -m "..."     (commit code changes)
```

Missing: Explicit step to run /dots-swe:code-complete

## Root Cause Analysis

### Why Current Protocol Fails

1. **No mention of code-complete**: Protocol goes straight from "bd sync" to "git commit"
2. **Ambiguous quality gates reference**: `.swe-context` mentions "run process-check before committing" but:
   - It's buried in middle of file
   - Says "process-check" not "code-complete"
   - Less prominent than SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL
3. **Competing guidance sources**:
   - SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL (from prime.sh) - most visible, missing code-complete
   - .swe-context Quick Reference - mentions process-check
   - .swe-context Quality Checklist - has checkbox but no enforcement
   - CLAUDE.md - mentions quality gates but less prominent
4. **Agent behavior**: Agents follow most structured/prominent guidance
   - SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL is in big header box
   - Presented at session start
   - Agents treat it as authoritative checklist
5. **Distinction unclear**: Difference between process-check vs code-complete not explained
   - process-check: Run quality gates only (interim checks)
   - code-complete: Quality gates + push + label + bead update (final step)

### Impact

- Agents skip code-complete 80%+ of the time
- Quality gates bypassed
- Manual intervention required
- Pattern becomes normalized

## Solution: Explicit Code-Complete Step

Update SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL to make /dots-swe:code-complete a required, numbered step.

### Enhanced Protocol (Ephemeral Branch Mode)

```
🚨 SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL 🚨

CRITICAL: Before saying "done" or "complete", you MUST run this checklist:

[ ] 0. Run /dots-swe:code-complete
       ↓ This command does ALL of the following:
       • Runs quality gates (test/lint/build if detected)
       • Pushes code to remote (if upstream configured)
       • Adds swe:code-complete label to bead
       • Marks work ready for integration
       ↓ DO NOT proceed to next steps if this fails
       ↓ Fix issues and run code-complete again

[ ] 1. git status              (verify what changed)
[ ] 2. git add <files>         (stage code changes)  
[ ] 3. bd sync --from-main     (pull beads updates from main)
[ ] 4. git commit -m "..."     (commit code changes)

Note: This is an ephemeral branch (no upstream). Code is merged to main locally, not pushed.

When code-complete fails:
• Read the error output carefully
• Fix the failing quality gate (test/lint/build)
• Run code-complete again
• Only commit after code-complete succeeds
```

### Enhanced Protocol (GitHub PR Mode)

```
🚨 SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL 🚨

CRITICAL: Before saying "done" or "complete", you MUST run this checklist:

[ ] 0. Run /dots-swe:code-complete
       ↓ This command does ALL of the following:
       • Runs quality gates (test/lint/build if detected)
       • Pushes code to remote
       • Creates/updates PR
       • Adds swe:code-complete label to bead
       ↓ DO NOT proceed if this fails

[ ] 1. bd sync --from-main     (pull beads updates from main)
[ ] 2. git status              (verify everything committed and pushed)

Next: Wait for PR review and CI to pass, then run /dots-swe:code-integrate
```

### Key Changes

1. **Step 0 is code-complete**: Most important step comes first
2. **Explains what it does**: No ambiguity about what happens
3. **Shows consequences**: "DO NOT proceed" language
4. **Failure handling**: Tells agent what to do if it fails
5. **Visual hierarchy**: Arrows show flow, emphasis on criticality
6. **Mode-specific**: Different protocols for ephemeral vs GitHub workflows

### Implementation

**File**: `dots-swe/scripts/prime.sh`

Update the SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL generation to:
1. Detect workflow mode (ephemeral vs GitHub PR)
2. Output appropriate protocol with Step 0
3. Detect if quality gates exist (test/lint/build)
4. Adapt messaging based on project type

**Example logic**:
```bash
# Detect quality gates
eval "$(detect_project_commands)"
HAS_QUALITY_GATES="false"
[ -n "$TEST_CMD" ] || [ -n "$LINT_CMD" ] || [ -n "$BUILD_CMD" ] && HAS_QUALITY_GATES="true"

# Output protocol
echo "🚨 SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL 🚨"
echo ""
echo "CRITICAL: Before saying \"done\" or \"complete\", you MUST run this checklist:"
echo ""
echo "[ ] 0. Run /dots-swe:code-complete"

if [ "$HAS_QUALITY_GATES" = "true" ]; then
  echo "       ↓ This runs quality gates:"
  [ -n "$TEST_CMD" ] && echo "       • Tests: $TEST_CMD"
  [ -n "$LINT_CMD" ] && echo "       • Lint: $LINT_CMD"
  [ -n "$BUILD_CMD" ] && echo "       • Build: $BUILD_CMD"
else
  echo "       ↓ No quality gates detected (no tests/lint/build)"
fi

echo "       • Pushes code to remote"
echo "       • Adds swe:code-complete label"
echo "       ↓ DO NOT proceed to next steps if this fails"
```

### Additional Enhancements

**Color/Emphasis** (if terminal supports):
- Red/bold for "CRITICAL"
- Yellow/bold for "DO NOT proceed"
- Green for checkboxes

**Validation Helper**:
Add quick check command: `/dots-swe:check-protocol`
Shows current step status:
```
Protocol Status:
  [✗] 0. code-complete - NOT RUN (no swe:code-complete label)
  [?] 1. git status    - unknown
  [?] 2. git add       - unknown
  [✓] 3. bd sync       - synced (0 minutes ago)
  [?] 4. git commit    - unknown
```

## Why This Works

1. **Prominence**: First thing agents see at session start
2. **Clarity**: No ambiguity about what to run
3. **Ordering**: Code-complete BEFORE commit (prevents skip)
4. **Education**: Explains what code-complete does
5. **Failure guidance**: Tells agent how to recover
6. **Reinforcement**: Repeated exposure builds habit

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Update prime.sh to output enhanced SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL
- [ ] Step 0 explicitly says "Run /dots-swe:code-complete"
- [ ] Explains what code-complete does (bullets)
- [ ] Includes "DO NOT proceed" warning
- [ ] Detects workflow mode (ephemeral vs GitHub)
- [ ] Outputs mode-specific protocol
- [ ] Detects quality gates and shows which will run
- [ ] Adapts message if no quality gates detected
- [ ] Visual hierarchy with arrows (↓) showing flow
- [ ] Test: prime.sh output in ephemeral mode
- [ ] Test: prime.sh output in GitHub mode
- [ ] Test: prime.sh with quality gates detected
- [ ] Test: prime.sh with no quality gates
- [ ] Update .swe-context template to match
- [ ] Document protocol in help.md

## Files to Modify

- `dots-swe/scripts/prime.sh` - Enhanced protocol generation
- `dots-swe/commands/prime.md` - Update documentation
- `dots-swe/commands/help.md` - Document protocol

## Testing Strategy

1. Run /dots-swe:prime in project with tests
2. Verify Step 0 shows code-complete
3. Verify quality gates listed
4. Run in project without tests
5. Verify "no quality gates" message
6. Test ephemeral mode message
7. Test GitHub mode message
8. Verify protocol appears in session startup

## Rollout Considerations

**Version**: Bump to 2.14.0 (protocol change is significant)

**Backward compatibility**: None needed (pure addition)

**Migration**: Existing sessions won't see new protocol until:
- Session restart, or
- Manual run of /dots-swe:prime

**Communication**: 
- Update README with new protocol
- Add changelog entry

comments.author: Robert (Kenpo) Evans
comments.text: Part of defense-in-depth strategy with oz4 (hook) and 9gg (instructions). This provides visual reminder via SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL.

title: Fix permission denied error on continue.sh script
description:
When executing the continue skill, users get:
```
Error: Exit code 126
(eval):1: permission denied: /Users/robert/.claude/plugins/cache/dots-claude-plugins/dots-swe/1.1.0/scripts/continue.sh
```

The script file is not executable. Workaround is to call with `bash` explicitly:
```
bash "$(ls -td $HOME/.claude/plugins/cache/dots-claude-plugins/dots-swe/*/scripts/continue.sh 2>/dev/null | head -1)"
```

Root cause: scripts are not being installed with execute permissions.
close_reason: Fixed script permissions. Scripts continue.sh, finish.sh, and swe-lib.sh now have execute permissions (mode 755). Version bumped to 1.1.1.

title: SWE agent should create beads when encountering script/tool errors
description:
## Context

When SWE agents encounter errors during their work (e.g., undefined functions, script failures, tool errors), they should create a bead to track the issue rather than ignoring it or just reporting it.

## Current Behavior

Agents may encounter errors like:
- `command not found` in shell scripts
- Undefined functions in tooling
- Failed quality gates
- Missing dependencies

These errors often get mentioned in output but aren't tracked for follow-up.

## Desired Behavior

Update swe.md agent instructions to:

1. When encountering a non-blocking error during work:
   - Create a bead with type=bug
   - Include error message, file location, and context
   - Continue with primary task if possible

2. When encountering a blocking error:
   - Create a bead with type=bug
   - Mark current bead as blocked by the new bug
   - Stop and inform user

## Example

```bash
# If agent sees: "get_integration_resources: command not found"
bd create --title="Fix undefined function: get_integration_resources" \
  --type=bug --priority=2 \
  --description="Error in code-integrate.sh:240 - function not defined in swe-lib.sh"
```

## Files to Update

- dots-swe/agents/swe.md - Add "Error Handling" section with instructions

title: Ensure SWE agents run quality gates before committing
description:
## Problem

SWE agents (including Claude) are skipping quality gates (process-check/code-complete) before committing code changes, violating the established workflow.

**Example:** dots-claude-plugins-ztt was committed and closed without running quality gates, despite guidance in .swe-context.

## Root Causes

1. **SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL incomplete**: Startup hook shows checklist without quality gates:
   ```
   [ ] 1. git status
   [ ] 2. git add <files>
   [ ] 3. bd sync --from-main
   [ ] 4. git commit -m "..."
   ```

2. **Competing guidance**: .swe-context says "run process-check before committing" but SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL doesn't mention it

3. **Todo lists miss the step**: Agents create todos for implementation but don't add "run quality gates" as a task

4. **No enforcement**: Nothing blocks commits without quality gate checks

## Impact

- Code committed without testing
- Quality issues slip through
- Protocol violations become normalized
- Defeats purpose of having quality gates

## Proposed Solutions

1. **Update SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL** in beads startup hook to include:
   ```
   [ ] 0. Run quality gates (/dots-swe:process-check OR /dots-swe:code-complete)
   [ ] 1. git status
   ...
   ```

2. **Update bead template** to include quality gates in acceptance criteria by default

3. **Add pre-commit guidance** in .swe-context that's harder to miss

4. **TodoWrite template**: When working on code, automatically include "run quality gates" as final step

5. **Documentation**: Update CLAUDE.md to emphasize this requirement more strongly
close_reason: Cannot modify bd prime - it's in beads-marketplace, not our codebase

title: code-complete should display bead metadata in summary
description:
The /dots-swe:code-complete command should display bead metadata (ID, title, description) in its final summary output.

Current behavior:
- code-complete runs quality gates and adds the swe:code-complete label
- Final summary doesn't include information about what was just built
- Users have to remember or check separately what the bead was about

Expected behavior:
- At the end of code-complete, display:
  - Bead ID
  - Bead title
  - Bead description
- This provides context about what work was just completed
- Helps when reviewing multiple completed beads

Example output:
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
✅ Code Complete: dots-claude-plugins-abc
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Title: Add user authentication
Description: Implement OAuth-based user authentication with GitHub provider

✅ Tests passed
✅ Lint passed
✅ Build passed
✅ Added swe:code-complete label

Files to modify:
- dots-swe/scripts/code-complete.sh (add bead metadata display)
- Use 'bd show <bead-id>' to fetch metadata
- Display after quality gates, before final success message

Benefits:
- Immediate context about what was accomplished
- Useful for documentation/changelog generation
- Better audit trail in session logs

title: Fix dispatch failing to open Ghostty tabs due to AppleScript permissions
description:
The /dots-swe:dispatch command creates worktrees and zmx sessions successfully, but fails to open new Ghostty tabs when invoked via the Skill framework. 

Root cause: The dispatch script uses AppleScript (osascript) to control Ghostty and System Events (swe-lib.sh:160-172), which requires macOS Automation permissions. When Claude Code runs the Skill tool, the AppleScript commands fail silently.

Possible solutions:
1. Add explicit error handling and permission checks for osascript
2. Provide clear error message when automation permissions are missing
3. Add fallback method or user instructions for granting permissions
4. Document the required permissions in setup guide

Impact: Users cannot bulk-dispatch work to multiple beads as intended.

title: Doctor command not found in plugin installation
description:
The `/dots-swe:doctor` command fails because the doctor.sh script is not included in the plugin installation.

Error:
```
Error: Exit code 127
no matches found: /Users/robert/.claude/plugins/cache/dots-claude-plugins/dots-swe/*/scripts/doctor.sh
```

The script exists in the source but is not being packaged/installed with the plugin.
close_reason: Fixed both issues. Added doctor.sh script that was missing from plugin installation. Updated beads sync check to treat missing sync.branch configuration as informational rather than an error. Version bumped to 1.1.3.

title: Fix Claude waiting indefinitely after Skill tool calls
description:
## Bug

Claude gets stuck waiting for output after calling the Skill tool, expecting automatic execution results that never arrive.

**Example Behavior:**
```
User: /dots-swe:code-integrate --local dots-claude-plugins-4y0

Claude: [Calls Skill tool]
Claude: "I see the skill instructions have been provided again. Let me wait for the actual execution output from the skill framework, as the instructions indicate the bash script will execute automatically."
Claude: [Waits indefinitely with no subagents running]

User: "What sub agents do you have running? You appear to be hung."
```

**Root Cause:**
The Skill tool instructions say "the bash script will execute AUTOMATICALLY" and "Wait for the skill execution output." This causes Claude to wait for output that doesn't come in the expected format, instead of checking status or running commands directly.

**Impact:**
- Session hangs requiring user intervention
- Poor user experience
- Wastes time and context

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Identify why Skill tool execution doesn't return output as expected
- [ ] Update skill instructions or framework to clarify expected behavior
- [ ] Add fallback logic: if no output after Skill call, check status directly
- [ ] Test with /dots-swe:code-integrate to verify fix
- [ ] Document correct pattern for using Skill tool with dots-swe commands

## Related Context

- Skill: dots-swe:code-integrate
- Framework: atomic-bash execution mode
- Session: This occurred after context compaction/summary

comments.author: Robert (Kenpo) Evans
comments.text: Fixed the hanging issue by updating all 11 command files with active Skill tool instructions. Changed from passive 'wait for AUTOMATIC execution' to active 'check the tool result immediately' with fallback logic. Created comprehensive documentation at docs/skill-tool-pattern.md.

comments.author: Robert (Kenpo) Evans
comments.text: This fix exposed a critical workflow bug: I didn't run quality gates before committing. Created dots-claude-plugins-65l (P0) to track the root cause and solution - we need to create our own prime command in dots-swe that includes quality gates in SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL.
